results.title: World Series Debating: That Football is Stupid
results.creator_credit: Andrew Denton, Ted Robinson, Joe Murray, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Wendy Harmer
results.brief_description: One of the most popular events of the annual Melbourne Comedy Festival, the debate was filmed over several years by ABC TV. Campbell McComas introduces two teams of 3 people consisting of Wendy Harmer, Edmund Capon, Lex Marinos, HG Nelson, Laurie Lawrence, Andrew Denton. The topic of this debate is that football is stupid.

results.title: The Leaving of Liverpool: Part 1
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, Steve Knapman, ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Broadcasting Corporation, BBC and John Alsop
results.brief_description:
Two English children - Lily (Christine Tremarco) and Bert (Kevin Jones) meet at the Star of the Sea orphanage in Liverpool. Lily has been placed there by her impoverished mother who needs to get on her feet financially, her pain at being separated is eased when she meets the spritely and nationalistic Bert. Together with the shy, hearing impaired Wilson (David Kaff), the three children decide to fly the flag for the empire and agree to go to Australia, their heads filled with ideas of forming a unified family in a warmer climate. This first part of the miniseries principally traces the fortunes of Wilson and Bert. Separated from Lily on arrival in Australia, they are taken to a religious rural establishment, St Bedes, where the boys are faced with gruelling manual labour, and a lack of mental stimulation or education. Bert is befriended by Brother O’Neill, while Wilson is subject to bullying.

From 1945, 10,000 children such as Lily and Bert were sent to Australia, under a child migration system which saw the removal of 130,000 youngsters from Britain. The program took place until 1967.

This version of events led to some of the migrants coming forward with their stories of abuse and neglect. Dubbed ‘The Forgotten Australians’, an official apology was made to them by Prime Minister of Australia, Kevin Rudd, in 2009.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Jenkins, Steve Knapman, ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Broadcasting Corporation, BBC and John Alsop

results.title: Locky by Night
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Astrid Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet Mark and Tanya the owners of the Lockington Hotel and share a night with the Lockington and Kotta and Rochester Instrumentalists (LAKARI) as they entertain the locals.

results.title: Lockington Living Heritage Complex
results.creator_credit: David Meagher, Astrid Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Celebrating and preserving the rich history of Lockington and its surrounding district, the dedicated and hard working volunteers of the Lockington Living Heritage Complex take us on a tour of the complex with the highlight being ‘The Big Shed’ which at 106 metres houses a restored Melbourne tram and the first ever pop top caravan, hand built in Lockington.

results.title: Living in Locky: The Youth Perspective
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Astrid Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: 17 year old Locky local, Emma McInnes interviews a cross section of young people to find out what life in a rural town is really like. What is there to do? What the future holds and the all important question, are there many lookers in Locky?

results.title: Ladies of Lockington
results.creator_credit: Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet the ladies who are at the heart of Lockington. These passionate and committed women get things done. They network, coordinate, manage and harness the talent that is available to them to improve and enhance the quality of life for all the families of Lockington and surrounding districts.

results.title: It's OUR Business: Lockington and District
results.creator_credit: David Meagher, Astrid Scott and ACMI

results.title: Love My Way: Garden of Love
results.creator_credit: Jessica Hobbs, Claudia Karvan, John Edwards, Foxtel, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Showtime, Southern Star Entertainment and Fiona Seres
results.brief_description:
The groundbreaking, multiple award-winning drama series ‘Love My Way’ was one of the first Australian productions made exclusively for subscription television (Foxtel). This enabled Foxtel to allow the producers ‘absolute creative freedom…to carve out a piece of TV drama that was edgy, daring, provocative’ (Foxtel’s Brian Walsh).

Revolving around the untidy lives and complicated loves of a contemporary Australian blended family and their friends, ‘Love My Way’ was both critically acclaimed and highly successful, with a further two seasons produced following the initial ten episodes of Series 1.

Series 1, Episode 10 first aired on Foxtel on 31st January 2005.
